awd_titl_txt: The role of tributaries in glacier surges
awd_abstract_narration: A glacier surge is characterized by a sudden increase in speed by one to two orders of magnitude and often leads to a significant movement of the terminus of the glacier. While the role of subglacial hydraulics during the surge has been well documented, the issue of surge initiation has remained unsolved. Also, the related question of why some glaciers surge and others do not remains open. This proposal will investigate whether the special geometry of many Alaska Range glaciers allows particularly large shear stresses to develop that eventually allow a surge to occur. The proposed work would focus on the Black Rapids Glacier on the Denali Fault in the eastern Alaska Range. The investigators contend that understanding glacier surges can also make a fundamental contribution to understanding of the basal boundary condition, which remains a major question in glaciology. As numerical models of ice flow are becoming more sophisticated, the issue of the basal boundary condition will have to be revisited and it is important to understand the strong non-linear aspects that lead to the switch from quiescence to surge. Lessons learned from surge initiation can also be applied to other situations where ice flows fast under high stress conditions, such as at fast outlet glaciers. The fieldwork would include radar to accurately map the base of the glacier, airborne lidar to generate a full digital elevation model of the surface of the glacier, GPS measurements of ice velocity, meteorological stations for climate data and ice ablation, and cameras to monitor the marginal lakes for drainage. These observations will be fully integrated with and complemented by a three-dimensional flow model of the glacier. The proposed work would form the core of a PhD thesis with training in field methods, data analysis, and numerical modeling. Scientific results will be presented at national and international meetings and in the peer-reviewed literature. Because glacier research tends to attract great interest among the general public, and Black Rapids is familiar to many Alaskans, this project is well-suited to public outreach. Outreach efforts will be coordinated through the institute's Information Office, which regularly schedules well-attended public talks and provides news columns about the institute's science activities.

por.por_cntn:
The extent of a glacier is governed by the rate of snow accumulation in the high areas and ice melt in the lower areas. Glaciers maintain an approximate balance between these quantities by flowing downhill, thus replenishing the melting ice at lower elevations. In a changing climate, the glacier extent adjusts in an effort to maintain balance between mass gain and mass loss. A small set of glaciers, however, shows unusual behavior: Decades of slow flow are interrupted by episodes of very rapid flow, up to a hundred times faster than normal. Such episodes are dramatic, produce lots of crevassing and can lead to an advance of several kilometers in a few months. These glaciers are known as surging, or galloping, glaciers.

 

Black Rapids Glacier in the Alaska Range was one of the first such glaciers where this behavior was documented during its 1936/37 surge. To date, many of the surge mechanisms remain unclear. It is known that lubrication by water at the glacier base plays an important role, but it is not clear why large quantities of water remain beneath the glacier in the first place. A simple theory suggests that the driving stress, the downhill component of the glacier's weight, plays an important role. But how some glaciers would allow this weight to build up to a critical value, while others don't, remains a puzzle.

 

The results of this work suggest that a critical factor for a buildup to surge geometry is the interaction of the main glacier with a tributary. The tributary glacier leads to a damming effect. This allows the weight of the glacier ice to build up to a surge state in the main branch. Most glaciers erode overdeepenings where tributaries join to accommodate the combined ice flowing from both branches. However, Black Rapids Glacier overlies an active geological fault. This displaces the location of where the tributary joins the main branch over time and might prevent this sort of overdeepening to develop. This is a potential explanation why surging glaciers often occur on geologic faults.

 

In this work we also addressed the likelihood of a future surge on Black Rapids, particularly in a warming climate. Measurements of surface elevations show that the glacier is no longer evolving towards a surge geometry. As a matter of fact, if projected climate warming continues, most of the glacier will have disappeared by the end of the century, even in areas where the ice is now over 600 m thick.

 

Despite the lack of a developing surge, a natural experiment occurs each year, where large amounts of water get to the glacier base when lakes at the glacier margin drain. We have documented how the glacier speeds up when such lakes drain and how this wave of faster moving ice propagates downglacier. We find that it temporarily switches the main supply of ice from one tributary to the other, just as happens during a surge. We can thus use these regularly occurring mini surges to better understand the rarely occurring big surges.
